Award.AwardTitle: Using Phylogenetic Structure to Clarify the Evolutionary Ecological Distribution of Microorganisms
Award.AbstractNarration:
Microscopic organisms, or microbes, are fascinating creatures because they exhibit an unparalleled diversity, can be found virtually everywhere in nature, and are responsible for critical ecosystem services. Advances in DNA sequencing technology have transformed how scientists study these evolutionary and ecological aspects of microbial life by providing genetic insight into which types of microbes live in specific environments. However, less is understood about how microbes have evolved the ability to thrive in these environments. This research project uses innovative methods to integrate evolutionary and ecological information about microbes to determine how they have evolved in particular environments and to discover evolutionary groups of microbes that are essential to the ecosystem. This work is important because (1) it will provide researchers with the tools needed to understand how evolutionary and ecological forces influence microbial biodiversity, (2) it will facilitate effective preservation of microbial ecosystems and their services, and (3) is will provide a means of efficiently engineering communities of microbes that are industrially valuable. Further, this research will provide valuable, fundamental insights regarding the mechanisms by which microbes evolve within the context of their ecosystem. In terms of broader impacts, this work is valuable because the tools generated will benefit future investigators in developing more quantitative analyses and research plans. The research team will also convene an annual bioinformatics workshop intended to bring in more under-represented and first-generation students.

This project will develop a set of eco-phylogenetic methods for assessing how and why specific groups of microbes diversify. Specifically, this approach analyzes phylogenies assembled from a set of microbial communities and profiles the presence and abundance of each evolutionary group (clade) in each community. It then identifies clades whose phylogenetic and ecological distributions indicate that specific evolutionary or ecological mechanisms have influenced their diversification. This includes development of statistical and model-based procedures to assess the likelihood that non-random processes created the observed patterns in community composition, diversification and relatedness. Finally, it will apply these methods to the study of mammalian gut and plant leaf associated microbial communities to determine which microbial clades are critical to the structure of these communities, co-evolving with their host, and subject to evolutionarily conserved interactions with other microbial clades.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant funded research that aims to improve our understanding of how microbes have evolved to live within the ecological conditions in which they reside. In particular, the funded research supported efforts to innovate methodology and theory that resolve phylogenetic clades of microbial taxa that statistically link to ecological covariates, indicating that the evolutionary group of taxa in question manifest a trait that in part underlies their distribution in nature. The investigative team also applied these methods to a variety of microbial communities, with a particular focus on clarifying how evolutionary groups of microbes -- as well as their traits -- link to the ecology and evolution of vertebrates, and also allow us to distinguish between samples drawn from different environments more effectively than traditional species units. As a consequence of these efforts, the investigate team produced (1) two novel and freely available software workflows that advance and improve microbiome analyses, (2) a novel mathematical framework that identifies clades that have diversified in association with ecological covariates as well as software that implements this approach, and (3) twelve scientific publications (to date) and multiple papers in the review process. Additionally, the investigative team trained a variety of researchers, ranging from undergraduates to senior postdoctoral scientists. Trainees supported by this grant have attained a variety of subsequent accomplishments: two postdocs matriculating into Assistant Professorships at R1 institutions, two trainees graduated with PhDs and are now postdoctoral scientists at other institutions, a trainee has nearly completed a DVM/PhD, another trainee about to complete her PhD, a trainee completed a Master?s degree, and a litany of undergraduate students obtained exposure to research that propelled their career progress. Moreover, the investigators have expanded awareness of their project accomplishments and microbiome science in general through a variety of efforts, including (1) myriad public lectures about microbiomes, (2) the development and implementation of workshops in microbiome data science that have collectively served over 100 trainees and faculty members, (3) integration of project discoveries into course lectures and laboratories, and (4) support of high school students participating in summer STEM research camps. These efforts have especially emphasized the importance of considering evolutionary theory in our understanding of microbiome research. Collectively, this grant supported the advancement of impactful methods, theories, and discoveries as well as teaching and training that center on integrating our knowledge of microbial evolution to transform our understanding of microbial communities.
